senses.de: A punishment given out as a result of breaking a rule or law.
senses.ex: He had to pay a penalty for parking his car in a no-parking zone.

Tips.title: Rule Violation
Tips.description: Penalty often relates to specific regulations or codes being broken.
Tips.example: The company faced a penalty for violating environmental regulations.

Tips.title: Legal Consequences
Tips.description: Penalty in legal contexts can lead to fines or imprisonment depending on the offense.
Tips.example: For tax evasion, she was given a stiff penalty.

Tips.title: Severity Varies
Tips.description: Penalties can range from minor to severe, reflecting the seriousness of the breach.
Tips.example: Not wearing a seatbelt could incur a small penalty.

senses.de: A disadvantage or negative outcome of a particular action or decision.
senses.ex: There's a penalty for withdrawing your money early from the savings account.

Tips.title: Negative Consequences
Tips.description: Penalty can also mean the negative effects experienced after choosing a certain action.
Tips.example: Ignoring the warnings, he faced the penalty of making a bad investment.

Tips.title: Hidden Costs
Tips.description: Sometimes a penalty can be unexpected costs or losses, not a formal punishment.
Tips.example: The penalty for canceling late was losing the deposit.

senses.de: In sports, a punishment given by an official for a rule violation.
senses.ex: The player received a penalty for aggressive behavior on the field.

Tips.title: Sports Infraction
Tips.description: Penalty in sports usually follows a foul or illegal action by a player or team.
Tips.example: A five-minute penalty was awarded for the late tackle.

Tips.title: Match Outcome
Tips.description: Penalties can influence the outcome of a game, making them critical moments in sports.
Tips.example: They lost the match due to a last-minute penalty.

senses.de: In a game or sport, a method of deciding a game or round when a score is tied after normal play.
senses.ex: The soccer match was decided by penalty shootout.

Tips.title: Decisive Play
Tips.description: A penalty in games is a chance to score or gain advantage, often to break a tie.
Tips.example: He scored the winning goal with a penalty shot.

Tips.title: Tense Moments
Tips.description: Due to their high stakes, penalty kick situations can be very tense and dramatic.
Tips.example: Fans held their breath during the penalty shootout.

Consequence.wordDefinition:
Consequence refers to the result of an action or decision, while the word penalty refers to a punishment imposed for violating a rule or law.

For instance, the consequence of not studying for a test is a bad grade, while the penalty for cheating on the same test might be suspension or expulsion.

In general, consequences are more broad and can be positive or negative, while penalties are specifically negative and often involve some sort of punishment.

Discipline.wordDefinition:
Discipline is a systematic approach to teach someone how to behave in a certain way or follow rules. It involves training, guidance, and positive reinforcement to encourage good behavior.

To sum it up, discipline is a positive approach to teach and guide someone, while a penalty is a negative consequence for not following rules or breaking the law.

Fine.wordDefinition:
Fine refers to a sum of money that someone has to pay as a punishment for breaking a law or rule. This is usually determined by a court or other authority.

For example, if someone is caught speeding, they might have to pay a fine.

Penalty refers to any form of punishment or consequence that someone faces for breaking a law or rule. This can include fines, but it can also include things like community service or even jail time.

For example, if someone is caught stealing, they might face a penalty of having to pay a fine and also doing community service.

Therefore, fines are a specific type of penalty that involves paying money, while penalties can refer to any punishment or consequence that is given for breaking a law or rule.

Forfeit.wordDefinition:
Forfeit refers to giving up something as a result of a rule or agreement that has been broken. For example, if a team does not show up for a scheduled game, they may forfeit the game and lose by default.

Forfeit means giving up something as a consequence of breaking a rule or agreement, while penalty means a punishment imposed for a rule violation.

Punishment.wordDefinition:
Penalty and punishment are often used interchangeably, but there is a slight difference in their meanings.

Punishment is more severe and involves some kind of negative consequence that is meant to be a deterrent against future behavior.

Punishment is usually levied by an authority figure such as a parent, teacher or a legal court. For example, losing privileges for misbehaving.

Overall, penalties are typically associated with minor rule infractions and have a predetermined outcome, while punishment is associated with more serious offenses and often involves a subjective response.

Reprimand.wordDefinition:
A reprimand is a verbal or written scolding or rebuke for not following rules or behaving appropriately.

It is usually meant to correct behavior rather than punish it. Reprimands are often given by authority figures, such as parents, teachers, or supervisors in the workplace.

In summary, penalties are harsher punishments for breaking rules or laws, while reprimands are corrective measures that aim to improve behavior.

Retribution.wordDefinition:
Retribution means seeking justice and repayment for harm done to someone. It is a form of punishment that is intended to make the person who did something wrong understand the harm they caused and to make things right.

Retribution can be used in both personal and legal contexts, such as seeking justice for a crime or seeking compensation for damages.

Sanction.wordDefinition:
Sanction refers to a punishment, restriction or limitation imposed as a consequence of violating a rule or regulation, usually by an organization, institution or group of people.

For example, a school might impose a sanction on a student who violates the dress code by prohibiting them from participating in extra-curricular activities, such as sports or clubs.

In other words, penalties are generally imposed by a governing authority, while sanctions are generally imposed by organizations or groups.

Penalties usually involve fines or legal repercussions, while sanctions often involve restrictions or limitations on privileges or activities.

quotes.Text: It has become increasingly difficult for states or the federal government to apply the death penalty. But why even try? Nothing is accomplished, and while the chances of making a mistake are now diminished - DNA can prove guilt as well as innocence - life in prison is a worthy substitute.
quotes.Title: American Journalist
quotes.Name: Richard Cohen

quotes.Text: I don't think I would want the responsibility for enforcing the death penalties. There's always the inevitable question of whether someone you gave the order to execute might truly have been innocent.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Jesse Ventura

quotes.Text: I do not throw myself down in the area, looking for a penalty, because I believe we should try to do things without being cursed and angry and without spitting on life.

quotes.Name: Paulo Dybala

quotes.Text: The death penalty not only takes away the life of the person strapped to the table - it takes away a little bit of the humanity in each of us.

quotes.Name: Clint Smith

quotes.Text: The devil has put a penalty on all things we enjoy in life. Either we suffer in health or we suffer in soul or we get fat.

quotes.Text: I am confident when I take the penalty otherwise I would pass for somebody else.

quotes.Text: I think life is sacred, whether it's abortion or the death penalty.

quotes.Text: I believe life imprisonment is far worse than the death penalty.

quotes.Text: Only those who have the courage to take a penalty miss them.

quotes.Text: Staying out of the penalty box will really help.
